Let $n\geq 1$ and\[A=\{a_1<\cdots <a_{\phi(n)}\}=\{ 1\leq m<n : (m,n)=1\}.\]Is it true that\[ \sum_{1\leq k<\phi(n)}(a_{k+1}-a_k)^2 \ll \frac{n^2}{\phi(n)}?\]



The answer is yes, as proved by Montgomery and Vaughan \cite{MoVa86}, who in fact proved that for any $\gamma\geq 1$\[ \sum_{1\leq k<\phi(n)}(a_{k+1}-a_k)^\gamma \ll \frac{n^\gamma}{\phi(n)^{\gamma-1}}.\]This general form was also asked by Erd\H{o}s in \cite{Er73}.

This is discussed in problem B40 of Guy's collection \cite{Gu04}.




References


[Er73] Erd\H{o}s, P., Problems and results on combinatorial number theory. A survey of combinatorial theory (Proc. Internat. Sympos., Colorado State Univ., Fort Collins, Colo., 1971) (1973), 117-138.

[Gu04] Guy, Richard K., Unsolved problems in number theory. (2004), xviii+437.

[MoVa86] Montgomery, H. L. and Vaughan, R. C., On the distribution of reduced residues. Ann. of Math. (2) (1986), 311-333.
